Award.AwardTitle: 4-manifolds, quantum field theory and generalized cohomology
Award.AbstractNarration:
In the first part of the project, the principal investigator will work on the topological classification of 4-dimensional manifolds, with an emphasis on infinite fundamental groups and the obstruction theory for embeddings of surfaces developed with Rob Schneiderman.
The second part of the project is joint work with Stephan Stolz on the relation between generalized cohomology and super symmetric quantum field theories. For space-time dimensions d=0,1,2 there are now well-defined notions of (d|1)- dimensional Euclidean field theories over a manifold X. For d=0 these are provably closed differential forms and for d=1 one obtains K- theory of X by taking concordance classes. It is conjectured that the case d=2 leads to the long desired geometrical/physical interpretation of classes in the universal elliptic cohomology theory of "topological modular forms" of Hopkins, Miller and Lurie. Evidence for this conjecture comes from the recently proven fact that the partition function of a (2|1)-dimensional Euclidean field theory is an integral modular form.

Both parts of the project relate methods from theoretical physics and mathematics. In the early 20th century, mathematical notions (like Riemannian geometry or functional analysis) were successfully used to explain physical theories (like relativity theory or quantum mechanics). In the second part of that century, the roles were somewhat reversed in that surprising predictions, mathematically provable only in very rare instances, were made by modern theoretical physics using notions like that of a quantum field theory. It is of ultimate importance for mathematical research to incorporate such notions into the body of well understood theories, hence providing both, progress in mathematics and a precise formulation of the basics of the physical theories. This project contributes to this goal via a particular relation between certain quantum field theories and some well understood cohomology theories in mathematics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Mathematics and Physics are tied together like a married couple, they need each other direly, one couldn't exist without the other. The partners are inspired by finding out more aspects of their spouses secrets and they move forward together through life, each buliding on the others progress. 

In the last century, one of them, physics, ran away a little bit from its partner. Only part of the known description of the forces in our universe are formulated in terms of solid mathematics. Given such a description, for example relativity theory (via Lorentzian geometry) or quantum mechanics (via spectral theory on Hilbert spaces), one can be sure that all predictions are valid and they can be computed very precisely. Today's GPS, present in almost every cell phone, could not work without the mathematical language for relativity. 

The other part of the so called "standard modell" is expressed in the language of quantum field theory, a part of physics that mathematicians are struggling penetrate. One can still do extremely precise computations but it's not 100% clear whether their outcome does, or does not, depend on the particular scientist performing it.

As a consequence, many groups of mathematicians set out to remedy the situation and it may not be an exaggeration to say that for several years, things are moving forward quickly on the mathematical side, slowly catching up with their partner again. 

This project is very much in the theme of this partnership. On one hand, I study 4-dimensional manifolds, like our universe, trying to find all ways in which it can curve and entangle itself. Together with Conant and Schneiderman we made some surprising progress on computing all Whitney towers in the 4-ball. This is a new tool in the area which will be needed for complete classification theorems in the future.

One the other hand, we are developing a precise notion of (functorial) super symmetric quantum field theories, jointly with Stolz and many others. We are relating the spaces of specific types of field theories to the classifying spaces of certain generalized cohomology theories. The hope is that the enormous machine of algebraic topology will be able to predict interesting results about the deformation classes of quantum field theories. As new results, we have formulated de Rham cohomology and K-theory in such a field theoretic language and are exploring a similar question for elliptic cohomology. We predict that the infamous Feynman path integral, ill defined mathematically in most scenarios, can be computed in terms of push forward maps in these cohomology theories.
